discoveredAssets: localhost:8080 - PHP/7.1.33 web application on Apache 2.4.38 (Debian) - Port 8080
http://localhost:8080/index.php - Main upload form endpoint - GET 200, POST form submission
http://localhost:8080/upload/ - Upload directory - 403 Forbidden (exists, directory listing denied)
Apache .htaccess - Server configuration file present - 403 Forbidden
PHP 7.1.33 runtime environment - End-of-Life version with known vulnerabilities

targets.objective: Test file upload functionality for arbitrary file upload vulnerability (RCE via PHP upload), MIME type bypass, path traversal in filenames, and assess upload directory execution permissions
targets.rationale: Simple file upload form with POST to index.php. Primary attack vector for file upload vulnerabilities. Need to test: unrestricted file types, double extension bypass (.php.txt), null byte injection, polyglot files, and verify uploaded files are not executable in /upload/ directory

targets.objective: Test for directory traversal via uploads, verify upload restrictions via .htaccess, check for race conditions in file naming, and assess if uploaded files can be accessed/executed
targets.rationale: Upload destination directory returns 403 (restricted). Testing whether uploaded files can be accessed outside the web root or if directory traversal is possible through upload filenames like '../../../' or '..' patterns

targets.objective: Research and test version-specific vulnerabilities in PHP 7.1.33 including known CVEs in file upload handling, session management, and remote code execution
targets.rationale: EOL version contains multiple known vulnerabilities. Should test for: session handling flaws, deserialization vulnerabilities, type juggling issues, and file upload specific CVEs affecting this version

targets.objective: Test for misconfiguration allowing PHP execution in upload directory, verify .htaccess restrictions, and check for handler bypass techniques
targets.rationale: .htaccess returns 403 (exists but inaccessible). Testing whether .htaccess properly prevents: PHP execution in /upload/, script execution (.php, .phtml, .php3), and shell access

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] PHP 7.1.33 identified - End-of-Life version (EOL since Dec 1, 2019) with known vulnerabilities including RCE, information disclosure, and file handling flaws
[HIGH] File upload application discovered at http://localhost:8080/ - Simple form with POST to index.php, primary attack surface for file upload exploitation
[MEDIUM] Upload directory /upload/ exists and returns 403 Forbidden - Directory listing prohibited but files may be accessible or executable
[LOW] .htaccess configuration file detected (403 response) - Indicates Apache restrictions in place but specific rules not accessible
[MEDIUM] No security headers observed (no X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, HSTS headers visible) - Potential for clickjacking or MIME sniffing attacks
[LOW] Application parameters (file, action, page) ignored - Input validation may be weak or parameters not implemented
[MEDIUM] Simple HTML form with no client-side validation - Server-side validation is critical and should be tested for bypass
[LOW] No API documentation, robots.txt, or sitemap exposed - Application surface is minimal and clear
